text: Its hard to say - this is not over yet. At the moment it seems like our volunteer base is loyal and ready to re start. Don't yet know about our clients. We are being approached for help on a one to one basis - loyalty of clients to our community events has yet to be tested. I am guessing that it will take some time to re build that base.
That the team can adapt to meet the needs of students. Positive team in challenging environment.
In time of need their werected funder that contacted us to see what they could do for us. Without that this community would have families without food.
There are homes for everyone if we look for them...
Alternative ways of working and of delivering services
Public service zealots don't know the needs and issues of businesses/ communities they are supposed to be serving
Pivot and be bold
Smart organisations survive!
Importance of networks
The speed of response at a local community level was galvanised faster than Government action
little impact day to day but future planning is hard. we come together for our conference once a year only anyway
Who could have planed for this. The need to have some reserves

Sharing knowledge and resources with other volunteer organisations, particularly during level 3 and 4. We had invaluable local online meetings during lockdown that occurred organically (not through formal organisation) that had key stakeholders and volunteer managers present. This was excellent for sharing resources and knowledge quickly and efficiently, as well as providing a space for managers to talk that I believe improved well-being for all of us during lockdown.
If i can get through the day that I am in then that's all that I need to be able to do - until tomorrow
How we can adapt to change
Benefit of being confident , positive ,adaptive and agile
Effective communication and engagement with our community

What fantastic volunteers and staff we have, I knew this but this has added to our awareness of what a great team we have, generous, caring and kind. The support and commitment of staff will get us through we hope.
Our daily communication with service users, staff and governance has been key.
That my members are quite independent
We are adaptable. We are too reliant on outside funding.
Establishing early an integrated team with diverse skills, knowledge and resilience are key to managing a major unforeseen situation.
How vulnerable we all are. How just listening and taking time to acknowledging others insecurities can help in so many ways. It costs nothing but can help so much.
He tangata he tangata he tangata...
staff & volunteer & client mental health well-being
My most important learning during this time has been the importance of moving quickly and adapting services efficiently.
The need for flexibility
We have an opportunity to work together more to build back better

Take time to stop and think. Never waste a good crisis. You need to have a clear understanding of the cost of winding down, and have that money set aside. We don't have enough funds to wind down solvently (should we want to). We're very interested in exploring collaboration around strategic themes and not just operational opportunities - i.e back of house functions.
the need to understand and recognize the different ways COVID 19 has impacted our stakeholder groups - and act and communicate accordingly and compassionately - one size does not fit all
People are not people without people.
There is a need in the pacific community and especially around families
That things can be more efficient
How to cope with staying home.
Keeping in touch with (& seeing) staff and Board during lockdown
Being able to quickly adapt to changes and appreciating the ability of our senior players to adapt to the changes.
Clear, brief messages for whanau
Donâ€™t be too reactive. A slow, well thought out approach is better
We can adapt easily
How important community sports facilities are to ensure good health and well-being to the local community. And the importance of our organisations volunteers.
Communities are resilient
Take time to consider
To be patient, kind and to deal with situations as they arise. To follow instructions in a timely manner
Resilience

Communities and local organisations have more capability/ability to effectively respond to local needs than big agencies/government/councils realise. while strong clear national leadership from Jacinda has been essential, top down/one size fits all responses from government do not enable/support local resilience and collective effort.
We operate very well from home and that there are huge benefits to delivering services online.
That government can respond quickly to need when it wasn't too. Let's continue to act quickly to deal will the pressing issues that we all know are there
That sometimes a tragic event can lead to opportunities â€¦.
Flexibility It's OK to feel anxious Attitude of positivism Looking forward and beyond
Online learning is actually easy and you can reach more people through it. It also takes a lot more time.
That's a big question!
Most important learning during this time is in how to prioritise our resources so as we are up & ready to start teaching again once we come into Level 1
That you cannot plan.for everything and that things can change very quickly
Keep those around you in a positive frame of mind... Kiwi can do!!
Flexibility
It Zoom, Go to meetings
How dependent our operations are on sport area viability
Ability to be nimble and fast acting - but in a considered manner
That we are a very strong community who are able to rally quickly and have some great systems in place to support our families.
communities are so important

To be able to manage the fears around COVID between our team has been challenging as it slowed down our decision making considerably, this made it difficult for me to make a decision as we almost lost a Trustee. I can't say I have learnt how to deal with the situation any better but it sure highlighted how different we all are when faced with a new situation like this.
How amazing our community is.
Clarifying organisational strengths.
That communities can survive difficulties if they feel they are understood and cared for.
think we over reacted
That collaboration is key. People are whakama (shy) so time building relationships and connections is key.

The personal bias often influences decisions by Boards who end up making negative or overly conservative decisions that will hurt them in the future. What is clear is the organisations who directly engage with and listen to a wide variety of stakeholders make well informed and bold decisions with a lot of support and understanding.
Importance of digital connectivity
that we can do this! What seemed scary way back at the start has been addressed and we have found ways to carry on
It's good to have a break but it's important to bounce back from it with new energy.
cancellation sucks
Zoom is good for a time

At times it was a struggle to get things right but then we were all struggling including the government - we all need to remember to be kind to each other and remember that we have never had to deal with anything like this before. Our learning and planning as we went up levels will put us in good stead to cope and act if we go up again - heaven forbid!
We can adapt quickly when needed. We can't go back to the old bureaucratic ways of operating now that we know how efficient we can be
That people are very resilient, and that we can be nimble and flexible for any situation.
That flexibility results in greater productivity.
We are small and unseen so undervalued. We need to focus on collaboration, marketing and diversity of services

Staff have contributed: strengths & weaknesses of remote learning, reinforcing that no matter how good our preparations, adults need to be ready to learn in order to engage. Memories of EQ brain... Reinforcing the importance of flexibility and creativity, and, above all, integrity
That In response to COVID we were asked to re-frame our work, which was exhausting. I know it had to happen, but going into the next project phase I wonder if I could have used the time more wisely.
We are able to be agile when we need to be and have been able to quickly shift delivery of services and seek funding differently.

That the majority of people have banded together to support each other and have staff have amazed us with their dedication and putting themselves out there. Surprisingly, and unfortunately, others have looked for opportunities for personal gain.
We can cope in a pandemic
How well we have managed to support clients and the families under level 4 & 3
That life can change utterly in the blink of an eye.
how different individual staff members deal with the change; that there are new opportunities for the way we deliver our services that we can now discuss out of necessity.
It was time to stop & review direction. Relearning that 'community counts' & local is the most important
That we don't have funds for technology so we were struggling to maintain our service.
That we need some younger volunteers
the need to keep communication with the members open at all times.
That quick and decisive action is required in this context
Virtual delivery of services. With added efficiency of virtual communications - have had more opportunity to get "off the tools" and work on bigger picture.

Having an office is a good thing. Going 'into work' results in more productivity than working from home. Surprisingly that our clients seemed just as happy with having telephone contact in lieu of home visits.
Collaborate with others
Make as much noise as possible, don't give up and try to communicate with the highest authorities available within departments

We are a charity serving charities for digital inclusion of their own organisation and of their clients. I learnt the lengths small organisations went to so they could continue to deliver services to their clients with their physical doors closed.
I have learned more about the strengths within our team. People are resilient and capable.
The arts is not yet fully understood as the powerhouse it is both economically and also for well-being.. there is a lot of kindness never the less in NZers!!
That our community is rock solid in support and that we can deal with anything by working together
Flexibility, agility
Service to community

Funding sources can evaporate over night. Whether decision making in a crisis sits with the management team or the Board (management team more pro-active/ quick decisions, Board risk adverse). Our distributed working/ service delivery model works well.
expect the unexpected
How to manage a remote team and the gaps in relationships and information sharing that emerge over time (not evident immediately) due to the lack of face to face engagement.

We need to move from our neo-liberal capitalistic economy that is based on infinite growth in a finite world. It is unsustainable. COVID-19 has shown us how vulnerable we are re our health and economy
We are resilient and agile. Our team has a positive attitude that has an upwardly cycling impact
we were out of control, had to comply with restrictions.
That the quietness has allowed artists to create - there will be enormous output if the mechanisms to share with the public can be put in place.

Working with the challenges of working from home, working effectively within restrictions to support our volunteers and members. Keeping motivated when staff pay increases and additional hours cannot be funded.
Staff being able to work from home. Using online services more
How valuable and important our philanthropy is to our community. Without us many NFP organisations would most likely not be able to operate under their own funding
Be Patient
Learning so much more about each other
In a rural area community support , caring for other people and connecting with each other really stood out
You cant take anything for granted
The C&V sector has shown that when there is need, the community can come together to support each other in various ways of sharing and caring..
What an amazing community we have and how everyone has pulled together to assist one another. The comment is how quick everyone was to respond.

The level and type of vulnerability within the community is both greater than we realised and more diverse than we knew. Under this type of situation, many of the psycho-social challenges that previously flew under the radar became much more visible.
to be flexible
That a person / community led approach is highly effective and will be critical to foster well-being as the recession bites.
value of committed volunteers
Maintaining the health and well-being of essential staff

Reducing bureaucracy has led to a much more efficient process and successful fundraising and grant-making campaign. We are also too reliant on grants and need to look for other ways to support our operational costs and growth.
The need for open communication between all our partners
How valued our service is to our service users
Be flexible and agile to move quickly.

People are amazing. The innovation we have seen has been nothing short of a miracle - both by staff and community members. It has been so inspiring. The second thing is that communication is king. We became much better communicators with our staff and volunteers and have seen the benefits of this.
How adaptable the staff are. The need for people of all ages and abilities to have digital literacy and own a device that they are confident to use and can afford to own.

The need for businesses to be embracing remote and digital approaches to working so that they can at a minimum can continue to operate, and beyond that, to be able to be more efficient and grow their impact.

That our organisations can move quickly to respond to challenges. our staff are resilient and dedicated in the face of significant personal financial sacrifice. our supporter community is very invested in the continuing existence of our organisation.
We have learnt that we have a lot of untapped skills and knowledge amongst our staff team
that people are important
How vulnerable we are in the arts
Importance of financial management
The ability to operate remotely and how that increases accessibility into the region through online offerings.
Some of my work has received some real discussion from a wide range of people and organisations. Still not convinced however that ideas can be freely discussed.
Never underestimate the value of kindness.

Working from home was very productive. The community response was amazing and which encouraged people to come forward for help, support and advice. The generosity of people was remarkable. The government handled the situation so well. Our City Council and the welfare team were great. people were very grateful for the support. It is was good to see humanity at its best.
Be flexible and carry on supporting as best we can
If weâ€™d closed our borders before the virus got in we could all have been operating as normal
Keep talking to similar organisations
How adaptable we can be.
That whilst most of business should be face-to-face, we can still provide good quality support remotely via phone and online.
Openness to new ways of working, and the value of professional networks.
Family is priority the rest is a nice thing to have
Take nothing in life or work for granted and seek new and innovative ways to progress our organisation
my learning has been about how to exist with what I have over the years done, gardening, living off the fruits of the feijoa, bottling the fruit, cleaning and get things in order.
different ways to connect with those we support

- Service provision that is meaningful when digital ?! - Balance of communication levels - fragility of arts sector and reliance on tangible experience - continued need for cross sector partnerships - realisation that national government bodies are slow to respond, and have shown to be disconnected from the sectors in which they represent
Support for families is always needed.
Our staff worker twice as hard during COVID-19. That the whanau we support live social distancing which is their norm. That support didn't necessarily reach those that needed it.
'Impossible is nothing' Communication - timely The true value of the team Importance of good leadership and direction - decisive communication of changing procedures
Anything is possible if you have the right people around you to share the responsibilities and you just need to roll up your sleeves and do not give up
That we are resilient and we will survive
Our people are the most important to us, we can run our business from anywhere
I am so proud of our team staff and board for their commitment to our core values. We were tested and we were true.
Need for strong and experienced governance and leadership. Not to over-react but remain flexible
Resilience and stoicism of our carers and their loved ones during this difficult time.
Power of collaboration
awareness of the community

Having been through the CHCH earthquakes our organisation had experience of having to adapt our services and respond to evolving need. We drew on this when exploring how we could respond to the community we work in where most people don't have access to IT and once again learnt the strength of encouraging neighbours to support neighbours and the power of community newsletters as a way of communicating helpful information and health messages.
There is way too much replication of groups administration and strategic planning. Competitive funding is killing group energy.

How vulnerable our organisation is and how we are not sustainable and the uncertainty of funding. How time consuming and stressful it is to meet new compliance around COVID-19 on top of the existing work load. For example: Funder who gave us a 7 year multi-year grant, advised they have stopped the funding process to work through a new process. We have not had a response to our question to the funder regarding whether this affects our multi-year grant. The community sector is no longer sustainable in its current format and needs to change, even it means that small organisations like ours has to close.
Trying out new ideas and going online to deliver educational activities.
We can work from home and at distance.
We rely too heavily on me to support and give information,, make decisions and run our facilities but because we are small then I run into a real problem with up-skilling others to do the role

We need to be flexible and adaptable. Thankfully we had the technology but had to learn it. Relying on this created some anxiety amongst our team. And that those we support rely heavily on in person, group or face-to-face contact, we struggled to find a way around this.
New Zealanders are particularly creative and innovative.
Always have money aside for a "rainy day".

That we are an adaptable and nimble organisation that is able to respond quickly to change. We are innovative with a strong sense of community. People reached out and helped and supported each other. That we as an organisation have been wise to have low overheads.
Good and flexible staff is everything
co-creation and having staff/committee members with the same vision
The importance of continuing to restructure to meet community needs
Keep the information flowing to everyone
Leadership is critical.
Being responsive in a best practice way
Confirmed we can adapt to change as an organisation.

How important the club is for socialising and togetherness. Many of our members are seriously old and for them the weekly, or bi-weekly, get-together at the club is terribly important. They were denied that during the COVID lockdown.
NZ is the best place to be. I am reassured by our government having done a great job.

Resilient of families to support each other, ability for men to learn new skills e.g baking and cooking, the remarkable efforts of families to learn and use technology e.g. zoom to connect and continue to run church programmes online, majority share positive messages and agreed to stay home to save lives
That technology is a powerful tool
To learn how to be strong and support one another.
Being a small organisation with established systems for working online meant we were able to respond quickly and effectively.
connections and whanau - our environment and culture
we can operate on line and the sector values this

I have learnt so much about our clients. I have rung each client every week to check on how they have been doing during the lockdown. This has allowed relationships to be created between myself and the clients which perhaps might not have happened. They have invited me into their lives.
As an organisation that provides essential critical services we faced an amount of vulnerability based on staff make up and conditions. The importance of strong, stable and empathetic leadership.

In a crisis people will step up to help - however the way in to volunteering during a crisis can be tied up in too much red tape. When people want to help -, they want to help now - NGOs, Council and Government need to look at better, quicker, processes for volunteer engagement. Communication is key - make sure you have up to date contact details available where they are needed.
Good communication with volunteer members
We need to ensure our bcp is better designed for the future
Have been impressed with the resilience of our Members on the way they have coped with the isolation and remained positive throughout.
to keep the focus on our vision and mission central, even if that means reducing some programmes
Never take for granted that things will always be the same.
stay flexible, cut back on costs, reply on support from Festival fans, make shows inexpensive
Sometimes a pause can help you evaluate your priorities and consider new service opportunities that reflect community need.
a sneeze can shut down many industries and wreck many lives.
the value of having an awesome TEAM ... (I already knew that though)
1. The importance of a good sound base of people to draw from

There are no leaders and barely any collaboration until it is forced upon people. Also that there are agendas behind some organisations, and it has very serious long-term consequences on the relationships and funding resources in every area of the country.
Slowing down a little made be reflect that "busy" is often used as code for "successful" - but over COVID-19 I think 'intentional" and "relationship-focused' are better indicators of success.
People are anxious about the coming months
There are different forms of danger
Financially we were well prepared but technologically we are still back in the 1980s and we can improve that
We have learnt to adapt and make the most of things. Online meetings were a very important way of keeping our programme alive and also connecting with our members
That fear motivates only 80% of the population
The precarious nature of community and social services relying on gaming grants to fund wages and to run their services. It's not sustainable and its not equitable.
How suddenly operations can change - be prepared for any eventuality.
Less dependence on bricks and mortar, flexibility to evolve into more digital delivery
The need to act quickly
The need is real
Having a cash reserve is very important and helps survive unexpected events. Can often be hard explaining the reason for a club having cash in the bank.
that we are all interconnected despite the 'lock' that we had lots to be grateful for here in NZ
Not to take things for granted
That volunteering needs a professional core
The need to be adaptable re mission & activity & ways of working

How agile we can be and how we can speed up decision making.

Communities and society in general rely heavily on the generosity of the volunteer sector
The value and importance of being able to adapt quickly. The value and importance of supporting the team (and the team supporting each other) to navigate their feelings, capacity and needs
That there are more organisations stretched financially and competing for fewer dollars from funders and donors.
Our work continues to be important
Adapting to new ways in continuing the services, such as virtual.
We live in a house of cards and need to delicately restructure into a solid frame for future resilience

Planning

How to provide service to clients without meeting in person. Particularly getting documents signed for those people who don't have laptops, scanners, printers.
Some voluntary organisations and charities are no different from businesses. They just donâ€™t pay wages. They have been completely ignored.
Being flexible
Our people are the most important part of our service - our clients and their families, the staff and volunteers.
The importance of being flexible and able to react quickly to new circumstances.
need to be agile and flexible to change to meet the needs of community members and also the environment
Haven't had time to evaluate.

That there is still a strong sense of community in NZ. When we need to, we can rise above individualism and act collectively. People are largely trying to do their best with what they have and support each other.
How vulnerable our older folk are when they are not able to access online supports and don't have whanau.
That we are not classed as an essential service.

1) We have developed some new budget tracking tools which have become invaluable at this time. 2) It has become very clear that very few people (including those in Government and media) have very little understanding of our sector, what we do and our impact in the community.
How to use different resources and how to reach out to people
The importance of digital media to stay connected and operating.
That we have come together to cope during this time, helping each other
How to operate under trying conditions
How quickly the ability to fundraise disappears when there is no access to general public and no ability for the club to meet.
Be adaptable and flexible
Having a contingency fund of at least 1 years finance to cover such happenings.
To take time to be still and slow the pace of life and to connect with people rather than being too busy.
That people need to look after each other. Volunteers are often stretched in their commitments. To say no.

That working from home is do-able with less effort/travel. The importance of having a bi-cultural liaison who understands the specific Asian culture and traditions and is able to address the people's concerns within the NZ setting.
Managing fluctuations in staff well-being and morale while still trying to deliver a service - it can be done but it takes a huge amount of energy

That our volunteers are elderly and we donâ€™t have enough youth assisting so our group became those in need ... and that those in need in our group didnâ€™t get the support that they had offered and done for others for so many years - sad but way of the world
We can survive - and hopefully thrive.
There are many ways to do things- we just need to be up for it!
The value of technology which can bring together our members from throughout NZ
Our specific Pasifika community live in crowded homes, are essential workers, have become unemployed during COVID 19 and its affected their mental health.
To be responsive to changes and being able to adapt easily, and giving our team - time to breathe....
Relationship building
Grassroots can achieve a large amount based on the generosity of volunteers
How people respond well to collaborative ideas and if you take the leadership they are can respond quickly. How effective remote learning can be. Also how effective meetings can also be using zoom
How versatile the use of zoom is
working from home is possible in various levels to be integrated as suits.
How we worked together as a national team, the collaboration and adapting to working from home. How our volunteers were determined to maintain their community service where possible.
Limitations on what we can offer
That we can be incredibly nimble to respond quickly to the needs of those we support.
We can survive and manage whatever the crisis
Sometimes there needs to be a burning platform within the sector to effect needed change. COVID-19 is presenting one of those.
How easy it is to work from home.
We need to be more resilient as a nation and as a region.
Be patient Communicate
Organisations that are smaller and more nimble seem to be flourishing as they pivot to support there communities. Larger more institutionalised orgs are struggling.
Cooperation
Our team is more agile and innovative than they ever thought they could be - has grown their confidence in themselves.
Being adaptable to new ways of doing business

Our strength is in our people, but without a place available to meet and a public health situation allowing us to meet, the organisation will fail. Financially we run to stand still, paying rent which exceeds our trading income making us grant dependent
People need interaction with each other. Social contact
Awareness

The importance of the collective approach. Government and NGO sector working together. there have been some stunning outcomes as a consequence. 2). Our small good leadership pool has been stretched to almost breaking point. We need to strengthen our leadership capacity
That community and people, not economy need to be the priority
The development of capability within our organisation for complete remote working. This has hastened the switch to (almost) paperless board meetings, which was previously taking forever to achieve.
Our expectations of product quality exceed the customers expectations and they bare actually happy with a lower standard of quality.
How people and organisations can adapt quickly to respond to a common threat
coping within financial limits
The value of people
Some of our members are very selfish
The way we present our selves to the public. There has been a emphasis in interactivity in the past- this may have to change in the long term. Use social media more diligently.
How quickly an organisation can adapt and deliver new initiatives
The resilience of the team, they have been great!
Life is to short and we don't need to be bogged down and over work. Meeting don't need to be face to face we can use more technology and work more flexible hours
How to operate as an essential service to provide security to our volunteers and our clients
Zoom.
People hold their passion and stay on board if the organisation shows its operations have been well thought out. Fear and anxiety are tangible for many. Opportunity knocks
Priorities
How to adapt to changing circumstances without our members feeling neglected
How to wash my hands very well.
to continue to keep in touch with our club members and adjust to the restrictions put in place throughout NZ
do we need to have an office. and staff who you think manage change found it very hard and those who I think need support were the ones who surprised - learning never think you know someone!
How useful it was collaborating on fund delivery for our regionâ€™s COVID-19 Emergency Response Fund with MSD, Civil Defence and DHB.
That we will survive and move forward

Not to rush matters ,take a deep breath as the environment is constantly changing. Be considered in what you do. People react to stress differently make allowances for this. Encourage and provide staff with the environment to be innovative.
The amazing resilience of the sector
The importance of community and viewing this as an opportunity for reflection and change
Sometimes we need to accept we cannot plan ahead, we just need to adjust to each day's events as they come.
Adapting to the technology.
Be patient don't panic stay flexible
How "fit for purpose" our staff are as a collective and the value they individually bring to strengthen the team.
That New Zealanders continue to be generous, and that it's more important than ever to retain your presence in the market
It's reinforced the importance of communication: with team members, supporters and our community
People are social beings and require contact with each other and the opportunity to participate in activities they enjoy to stay physically and mentally well.

That a community knows their own community well. If funding or resources was filtered to grass roots groups/NGOs we would not be needing to do Post COVID planning to try and access funds now. We would have already set up systems already by now
How to provide IT solutions that are easy for the disabled to understand
There is an appetite to adjust rapidly to the changing needs of our communities.
That in low times communities come together.
That without Government support there would have been "collapse" of the organization and indeed the whole country.
self care staff care client care a stronger leadership from the Board of Trustees
Need for flexibility and work to meet the needs of the clients we serve.
How quickly our lives can be impacted from outside influences

Our business continuity plan was not sufficiently well defined for a Pandemic event like this, however it gave us a good base from which to start our crisis management. It needs to be reviewed and revised.

That the community and volunteer sector has been heavily relied on during the pandemic. This is the most underfunded sector and needs to be re-set by government. Critical services are being supplied by volunteers and this needs to be recognised at the highest level.
Being flexible and looking for alternate ways of doing things that serve our people.
How valuable the work we have done over the last two decades for these times
resilience
New ways of connecting our mentors, families and mentees
How amazing our team is. Great people who really care' Our limited understanding of new technology

That appropriately skilled, dedicated staff are key to adapting and putting in the hard yards to get results for the new normal. They now need to be supported for the long term so that they continue the good work and keep up their own health and well-being while delivering a large programme.
That our sector is very well placed to innovate and collaborate and deliver best outcomes to our communities. We just need space and resources to promote innovation and support change.
There was absolutely nothing our organisation could do during Levels 2 to 4 through the lockdown. Our executive used this time to complete compliance.
That we have to adapt to a new Normal, learning change is not a bad thing.
That what we do is valued, even if people aren't willing to pay for it.
that we can change the way we do things and still have an impact and work with in our values
Flexibility and capability of changes in the workplace.
That community organisations have met the needs of people in need
We are agile
Need for current information about household/resident population in the community to identify quickly the vulnerable in an emergency
It has been good to embrace the online opportunities - and without running fundraising events has allowed us a little more time to talk to our families and look at new ways we can help them.

Although the Government relies heavily on the NGO sector for health and social services to keep running, this reliance is not supported financially. I have learned that our organisation is one of many receiving very little or no support at all from Government.

That people don't like change. That it takes time and you've got to bring everyone with you. Sometimes you just have to slow down and listen and wait. That people need support to change. That where there is a will there is usually a way. That we need to go beyond our four walls and connect with people where ever they are.
That we need to expand and consolidate our operations under 1 roof. This will make us operate more efficiently
Our supporters are fabulous and were just waiting to be asked to help. We have a strong team with a supportive culture and that is what gets us through.
The resilience of most people to dig deep and remain contained
More important than the success of our activities, is that each person who is touch feels supported. Also, that if people don't have purpose or routine they become listless, bored, and sad.
To not get despondent but to look at other ways to work differently

Managers of small organisations do too much. There is not enough skill in the staff of small organisations. Services tend to employ people who are vulnerable in a crisis and this is a threat to service delivery in times of need if not managed well.
That we are a smallish community but we can work together for the common good
sadness
To focus on our core service and not let distractions get in the way

That Council funding is a significant risk and that risk needs to be spread among a variety of funding options to avoid a similar situation arising in future. Also whether our business model, which has operated since 1977, remains viable.

I have networked with more people during COVID-19 lockdown than I was able to prior to lockdown. Our agency has grown in terms of our ability to communicate both within the agency (it's often difficult to meet with casual staff), across government departments, with local organisations as well as with other providers in our same sector.
Appreciation of what we had
Good family time and relationships

Effective and timely communication is key - to stakeholders, to community, to end users, to staff. That people are very resourceful when they need to be. Our organisation is based on reciprocal support - people giving and receiving services and support from each other. This has huge benefits compared to a more charitable model - it is very disempowering when people feel they are always taking and are not contributing. The COVID experience has reinforced the value of reciprocity and facilitating a sense of contribution and value - people want to help, not always to be on the end of charity.

Schools that new their local community managed to engage far better with all their students. The government of NZ governed us citizens and protect us, not their countries of origin. The Ethnic communities should clearly understand their obligations to NZ. Resilience of grass roots community groups , their ability to read what is required and adapt accordingly . Inspiring growth of online activities to connect with vulnerable people .freedom from bureaucratic restraints for people to do whatever is required .

That a lot of charities in NZ don't have any sort of preparedness for, or resilience to, systematic shock. Consolidation needs to happen sooner rather than later to streamline our sector and make more efficient use of what will be a smaller pool of financial resources in the near to mid term future. There will be an increased reliance on volunteers, which will coincide positively (in as much as it can be positive!) with higher unemployment. This means volunteer management will become just as important, and charities who can harness this properly will thrive in the coming environment.
We all have to be prepared for something like this, if in fact it does happen again.
